transcript:
Patient: One of the biggest challenges I face with setting boundaries at work is the fear of disappointing my colleagues or my boss. I worry that if I say no to a task or project, they'll think I'm not a team player or that I'm not committed to my job.

Therapist: That's a valid concern, Alejandro. It's common to worry about how others perceive us, especially in a work setting. Let's explore this further. What do you think might happen if you were to set a boundary and say no to a task or project?

Patient: I'm afraid that my colleagues will think I'm lazy or not pulling my weight. And I worry that my boss might question my dedication to the job or pass me over for future opportunities.

Therapist: Those are understandable fears. Let's look at the evidence for and against these thoughts. Have you had any experiences where setting a boundary at work led to negative consequences?

Patient: Well, now that I think about it, there was one time when I told my boss that I couldn't take on an extra project because I was already at capacity. He seemed understanding and didn't make me feel guilty about it.

Therapist: That's a great example. It shows that setting a boundary didn't necessarily lead to the negative consequences you feared. In fact, your boss was understanding. Let's work on reframing these thoughts. Instead of thinking, "If I set a boundary, my colleagues will think I'm lazy," you could try, "Setting boundaries is a sign of self-respect and can help me maintain a healthy work-life balance." And instead of worrying about your boss questioning your dedication, you could remind yourself of the time when he was understanding about you not taking on an extra project.

Patient: That makes sense. I guess I need to challenge these fears and remind myself that setting boundaries is actually a positive thing.

Therapist: Exactly! Setting boundaries is a way of taking care of yourself and ensuring that you can perform at your best. It's not selfish or lazy. Let's create a specific plan for setting boundaries at work. What do you think would be a realistic and achievable goal for you?

Patient: I think a good goal would be to set at least one boundary per week, whether it's saying no to a task or project, or communicating my needs and limitations to my colleagues or boss.

Therapist: That's a great goal, Alejandro. Start small and build up from there. Remember, setting boundaries is a skill that takes practice. It's okay if you don't always get it perfect. The important thing is that you're making an effort to prioritize your well-being.

Patient: I'm feeling more empowered to set boundaries now. I know it won't be easy, but I'm willing to give it a try.

Therapist: That's wonderful, Alejandro. I'm glad you're feeling more empowered. Remember to be patient with yourself as you work on this skill. It's okay to take small steps and celebrate your progress along the way.

Patient: Thank you for the encouragement, Nova. I'm ready to start setting some boundaries at work.

Therapist: You're welcome, Alejandro. I have confidence in your ability to set healthy boundaries. Let's move on to discussing your feelings of guilt related to your children. Can you tell me more about what triggers these feelings?

Patient: I feel guilty when I have to work late or miss out on activities with my children because of work. I worry that I'm not being a good enough father and that they'll resent me for not being more present in their lives.

Therapist: It's understandable to feel guilty when you can't be as present as you'd like to be with your children. Let's explore these feelings further. What do you think makes you a good father, aside from the amount of time you spend with your children?
